Content: shall contain, at a minimum, the information set out in Annex XI for the purpose of providing it, upon request, to the AI Office and the national competent authorities;

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (b) draw up, keep up-to-date and make available information and documentation to providers of AI systems who intend to integrate the general-purpose AI model into their AI systems. Without

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: their AI systems. Without prejudice to the need to observe and protect intellectual property rights and confidential business information or trade secrets in accordance with Union and national

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: with Union and national law, the information and documentation shall:

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (i) enable providers of AI systems to have a good understanding of the capabilities and limitations of the general-purpose AI model and to comply with their obligations pursuant to this

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: obligations pursuant to this Regulation; and

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (ii) contain, at a minimum, the elements set out in Annex XII;

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (c) put in place a policy to comply with Union law on copyright and related rights, and in particular to identify and comply with, including through state-of-the-art technologies, a reservation

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: technologies, a reservation of rights expressed pursuant to Article 4(3) of Directive (EU) 2019/790;

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (d) draw up and make publicly available a sufficiently detailed summary about the content used for training of the general-purpose AI model, according to a template provided by the AI Office.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 2. The obligations set out in paragraph 1, points (a) and (b), shall not apply to providers of AI models that are released under a free and open-source licence that allows for the access,

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: that allows for the access, usage, modification, and distribution of the model, and whose parameters, including the weights, the information on the model architecture, and the information

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: and the information on model usage, are made publicly available. This exception shall not apply to general-purpose AI models with systemic risks.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 3. Providers of general-purpose AI models shall cooperate as necessary with the Commission and the national competent authorities in the exercise of their competences and powers pursuant

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: and powers pursuant to this Regulation.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 4. Providers of general-purpose AI models may rely on codes of practice within the meaning of Article 56 to demonstrate compliance with the obligations set out in paragraph 1 of this Article,

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: paragraph 1 of this Article, until a harmonised standard is published. Compliance with European harmonised standards grants providers the presumption of conformity to the extent that those

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: to the extent that those standards cover those obligations. Providers of general-purpose AI models who do not adhere to an approved code of practice or do not comply with a European harmonised

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: with a European harmonised standard shall demonstrate alternative adequate means of compliance for assessment by the Commission.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 5. For the purpose of facilitating compliance with Annex XI, in particular points 2 (d) and (e) thereof, the Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 97

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: in accordance with Article 97 to detail measurement and calculation methodologies with a view to allowing for comparable and verifiable documentation.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 6. The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 97(2) to amend Annexes XI and XII in light of evolving technological developments.

Article: Article 53: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 7. Any information or documentation obtained pursuant to this Article, including trade secrets, shall be treated in accordance with the confidentiality obligations set out in Article 78.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 1. Prior to placing a general-purpose AI model on the Union market, providers established in third countries shall, by written mandate, appoint an authorised representative which is established

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: which is established in the Union.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 2. The provider shall enable its authorised representative to perform the tasks specified in the mandate received from the provider.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 3. The authorised representative shall perform the tasks specified in the mandate received from the provider. It shall provide a copy of the mandate to the AI Office upon request, in one

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: Office upon request, in one of the official languages of the institutions of the Union. For the purposes of this Regulation, the mandate shall empower the authorised representative to carry

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: representative to carry out the following tasks:

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (a) verify that the technical documentation specified in Annex XI has been drawn up and all obligations referred to in Article 53 and, where applicable, Article 55 have been fulfilled by

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 55 have been fulfilled by the provider;

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (b) keep a copy of the technical documentation specified in Annex XI at the disposal of the AI Office and national competent authorities, for a period of 10 years after the general-purpose

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: after the general-purpose AI model has been placed on the market, and the contact details of the provider that appointed the authorised representative;

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (c) provide the AI Office, upon a reasoned request, with all the information and documentation, including that referred to in point (b), necessary to demonstrate compliance with the obligations

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: with the obligations in this Chapter;

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: (d) cooperate with the AI Office and competent authorities, upon a reasoned request, in any action they take in relation to the general-purpose AI model, including when the model is integrated

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: when the model is integrated into AI systems placed on the market or put into service in the Union.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 4. The mandate shall empower the authorised representative to be addressed, in addition to or instead of the provider, by the AI Office or the competent authorities, on all issues related

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: on all issues related to ensuring compliance with this Regulation.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 5. The authorised representative shall terminate the mandate if it considers or has reason to consider the provider to be acting contrary to its obligations pursuant to this Regulation.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: pursuant to this Regulation. In such a case, it shall also immediately inform the AI Office about the termination of the mandate and the reasons therefor.

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: 6. The obligation set out in this Article shall not apply to providers of general-purpose AI models that are released under a free and open-source licence that allows for the access, usage,

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: allows for the access, usage, modification, and distribution of the model, and whose parameters, including the weights, the information on the model architecture, and the information on

Article: Article 54: Authorised Representatives of Providers of General-Purpose AI Models
Content: and the information on model usage, are made publicly available, unless the general-purpose AI models present systemic risks.

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: 1. In addition to the obligations listed in Articles 53 and 54, providers of general-purpose AI models with systemic risk shall:

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: (a) perform model evaluation in accordance with standardised protocols and tools reflecting the state of the art, including conducting and documenting adversarial testing of the model with

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: testing of the model with a view to identifying and mitigating systemic risks;

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: (b) assess and mitigate possible systemic risks at Union level, including their sources, that may stem from the development, the placing on the market, or the use of general-purpose AI

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: the use of general-purpose AI models with systemic risk;

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: (c) keep track of, document, and report, without undue delay, to the AI Office and, as appropriate, to national competent authorities, relevant information about serious incidents and possible

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: incidents and possible corrective measures to address them;

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: (d) ensure an adequate level of cybersecurity protection for the general-purpose AI model with systemic risk and the physical infrastructure of the model.

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: 2. Providers of general-purpose AI models with systemic risk may rely on codes of practice within the meaning of Article 56 to demonstrate compliance with the obligations set out in paragraph

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: set out in paragraph 1 of this Article, until a harmonised standard is published. Compliance with European harmonised standards grants providers the presumption of conformity to the extent

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: of conformity to the extent that those standards cover those obligations. Providers of general-purpose AI models with systemic risks who do not adhere to an approved code of practice or

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: approved code of practice or do not comply with a European harmonised standard shall demonstrate alternative adequate means of compliance for assessment by the Commission.

Article: Article 55: Obligations for Providers of General-Purpose AI Models with Systemic Risk
Content: 3. Any information or documentation obtained pursuant to this Article, including trade secrets, shall be treated in accordance with the confidentiality obligations set out in Article 78.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 1. Member States shall ensure that their competent authorities establish at least one AI regulatory sandbox at national level, which shall be operational by 2 August 2026. That sandbox

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 2 August 2026. That sandbox may also be established jointly with the competent authorities of other Member States. The Commission may provide technical support, advice and tools for the

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: advice and tools for the establishment and operation of AI regulatory sandboxes. The obligation under the first subparagraph may also be fulfilled by participating in an existing sandbox

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: in an existing sandbox in so far as that participation provides an equivalent level of national coverage for the participating Member States.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 2. Additional AI regulatory sandboxes at regional or local level, or established jointly with the competent authorities of other Member States may also be established.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 3. The European Data Protection Supervisor may also establish an AI regulatory sandbox for Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, and may exercise the roles and the tasks of

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: the roles and the tasks of national competent authorities in accordance with this Chapter.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 4. Member States shall ensure that the competent authorities referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 allocate sufficient resources to comply with this Article effectively and in a timely manner.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: and in a timely manner. Where appropriate, national competent authorities shall cooperate with other relevant authorities, and may allow for the involvement of other actors within the AI

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: of other actors within the AI ecosystem. This Article shall not affect other regulatory sandboxes established under Union or national law. Member States shall ensure an appropriate level

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: ensure an appropriate level of cooperation between the authorities supervising those other sandboxes and the national competent authorities.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 5. AI regulatory sandboxes established under paragraph 1 shall provide for a controlled environment that fosters innovation and facilitates the development, training, testing and validation

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: testing and validation of innovative AI systems for a limited time before their being placed on the market or put into service pursuant to a specific sandbox plan agreed between the providers

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: agreed between the providers or prospective providers and the competent authority. Such sandboxes may include testing in real world conditions supervised therein.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 6. Competent authorities shall provide, as appropriate, guidance, supervision and support within the AI regulatory sandbox with a view to identifying risks, in particular to fundamental

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: in particular to fundamental rights, health and safety, testing, mitigation measures, and their effectiveness in relation to the obligations and requirements of this Regulation and, where

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: of this Regulation and, where relevant, other Union and national law supervised within the sandbox.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 7. Competent authorities shall provide providers and prospective providers participating in the AI regulatory sandbox with guidance on regulatory expectations and how to fulfil the requirements

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: to fulfil the requirements and obligations set out in this Regulation. Upon request of the provider or prospective provider of the AI system, the competent authority shall provide a written

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: shall provide a written proof of the activities successfully carried out in the sandbox. The competent authority shall also provide an exit report detailing the activities carried out in

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: the activities carried out in the sandbox and the related results and learning outcomes. Providers may use such documentation to demonstrate their compliance with this Regulation through

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: with this Regulation through the conformity assessment process or relevant market surveillance activities. In this regard, the exit reports and the written proof provided by the national

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: provided by the national competent authority shall be taken positively into account by market surveillance authorities and notified bodies, with a view to accelerating conformity assessment

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: conformity assessment procedures to a reasonable extent.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 8. Subject to the confidentiality provisions in Article 78, and with the agreement of the provider or prospective provider, the Commission and the Board shall be authorised to access the

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: be authorised to access the exit reports and shall take them into account, as appropriate, when exercising their tasks under this Regulation. If both the provider or prospective provider

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: or prospective provider and the national competent authority explicitly agree, the exit report may be made publicly available through the single information platform referred to in this

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: platform referred to in this Article.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 9. The establishment of AI regulatory sandboxes shall aim to contribute to the following objectives:

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: (a) improving legal certainty to achieve regulatory compliance with this Regulation or, where relevant, other applicable Union and national law;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: (b) supporting the sharing of best practices through cooperation with the authorities involved in the AI regulatory sandbox;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: (c) fostering innovation and competitiveness and facilitating the development of an AI ecosystem;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: (d) contributing to evidence-based regulatory learning;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: (e) facilitating and accelerating access to the Union market for AI systems, in particular when provided by SMEs, including start-ups.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 10. National competent authorities shall ensure that, to the extent the innovative AI systems involve the processing of personal data or otherwise fall under the supervisory remit of other

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: supervisory remit of other national authorities or competent authorities providing or supporting access to data, the national data protection authorities and those other national or competent

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: other national or competent authorities are associated with the operation of the AI regulatory sandbox and involved in the supervision of those aspects to the extent of their respective

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: extent of their respective tasks and powers.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 11. The AI regulatory sandboxes shall not affect the supervisory or corrective powers of the competent authorities supervising the sandboxes, including at regional or local level. Any significant

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: local level. Any significant risks to health and safety and fundamental rights identified during the development and testing of such AI systems shall result in an adequate mitigation. National

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: adequate mitigation. National competent authorities shall have the power to temporarily or permanently suspend the testing process, or the participation in the sandbox if no effective mitigation

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: if no effective mitigation is possible, and shall inform the AI Office of such decision. National competent authorities shall exercise their supervisory powers within the limits of the

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: within the limits of the relevant law, using their discretionary powers when implementing legal provisions in respect of a specific AI regulatory sandbox project, with the objective of

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: with the objective of supporting innovation in AI in the Union.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 12. Providers and prospective providers participating in the AI regulatory sandbox shall remain liable under applicable Union and national liability law for any damage inflicted on third

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: any damage inflicted on third parties as a result of the experimentation taking place in the sandbox. However, provided that the prospective providers observe the specific plan and the

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: the specific plan and the terms and conditions for their participation and follow in good faith the guidance given by the national competent authority, no administrative fines shall be

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: administrative fines shall be imposed by the authorities for infringements of this Regulation. Where other competent authorities responsible for other Union and national law were actively

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: national law were actively involved in the supervision of the AI system in the sandbox and provided guidance for compliance, no administrative fines shall be imposed regarding that law.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 13. The AI regulatory sandboxes shall be designed and implemented in such a way that, where relevant, they facilitate cross-border cooperation between national competent authorities.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 14. National competent authorities shall coordinate their activities and cooperate within the framework of the Board.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 15. National competent authorities shall inform the AI Office and the Board of the establishment of a sandbox, and may ask them for support and guidance. The AI Office shall make publicly

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: AI Office shall make publicly available a list of planned and existing sandboxes and keep it up to date in order to encourage more interaction in the AI regulatory sandboxes and cross-border

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: sandboxes and cross-border cooperation.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 16. National competent authorities shall submit annual reports to the AI Office and to the Board, from one year after the establishment of the AI regulatory sandbox and every year thereafter

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: and every year thereafter until its termination, and a final report. Those reports shall provide information on the progress and results of the implementation of those sandboxes, including

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: of those sandboxes, including best practices, incidents, lessons learnt and recommendations on their setup and, where relevant, on the application and possible revision of this Regulation,

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: revision of this Regulation, including its delegated and implementing acts, and on the application of other Union law supervised by the competent authorities within the sandbox. The national

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: the sandbox. The national competent authorities shall make those annual reports or abstracts thereof available to the public, online. The Commission shall, where appropriate, take the annual

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: appropriate, take the annual reports into account when exercising its tasks under this Regulation.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 17. The Commission shall develop a single and dedicated interface containing all relevant information related to AI regulatory sandboxes to allow stakeholders to interact with AI regulatory

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: interact with AI regulatory sandboxes and to raise enquiries with competent authorities, and to seek nonbinding guidance on the conformity of innovative products, services, business models

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: services, business models embedding AI technologies, in accordance with Article 62(1), point (c). The Commission shall proactively coordinate with national competent authorities, where

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: competent authorities, where relevant.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: 1. In order to avoid fragmentation across the Union, the Commission shall adopt implementing acts specifying the detailed arrangements for the establishment, development, implementation,

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: development, implementation, operation and supervision of the AI regulatory sandboxes. The implementing acts shall include common principles on the following issues:

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation

Content: (a) eligibility and selection criteria for participation in the AI regulatory sandbox;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: (b) procedures for the application, participation, monitoring, exiting from and termination of the AI regulatory sandbox, including the sandbox plan and the exit report;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: (c) the terms and conditions applicable to the participants. Those implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 98(2).

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: 2. The implementing acts referred to in paragraph 1 shall ensure:

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: (a) that AI regulatory sandboxes are open to any applying provider or prospective provider of an AI system who fulfils eligibility and selection criteria, which shall be transparent and

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: shall be transparent and fair, and that national competent authorities inform applicants of their decision within three months of the application;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 58: Detailed Arrangements for, and Functioning of, AI Regulatory Sandboxes

Article: Article 61: Informed Consent to Participate in Testing in Real World Conditions Outside AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: (e) the Union-wide unique single identification number of the testing in real world conditions in accordance with Article 60(4) point (c), and the contact details of the provider or its

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 61: Informed Consent to Participate in Testing in Real World Conditions Outside AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: of the provider or its legal representative from whom further information can be obtained.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 61: Informed Consent to Participate in Testing in Real World Conditions Outside AI Regulatory Sandboxes
Content: 2. The informed consent shall be dated and documented and a copy shall be given to the subjects of testing or their legal representative.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: 1. Member States shall undertake the following actions:

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (a) provide SMEs, including start-ups, having a registered office or a branch in the Union, with priority access to the AI regulatory sandboxes, to the extent that they fulfil the eligibility

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: they fulfil the eligibility conditions and selection criteria; the priority access shall not preclude other SMEs, including start-ups, other than those referred to in this paragraph from

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: to in this paragraph from access to the AI regulatory sandbox, provided that they also fulfil the eligibility conditions and selection criteria;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (b) organise specific awareness raising and training activities on the application of this Regulation tailored to the needs of SMEs including start-ups, deployers and, as appropriate, local

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: and, as appropriate, local public authorities;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (c) utilise existing dedicated channels and where appropriate, establish new ones for communication with SMEs including start-ups, deployers, other innovators and, as appropriate, local

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: and, as appropriate, local public authorities to provide advice and respond to queries about the implementation of this Regulation, including as regards participation in AI regulatory sandboxes;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (d) facilitate the participation of SMEs and other relevant stakeholders in the standardisation development process.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: 2. The specific interests and needs of the SME providers, including start-ups, shall be taken into account when setting the fees for conformity assessment under Article 43, reducing those

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: Article 43, reducing those fees proportionately to their size, market size and other relevant indicators.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: 3. The AI Office shall undertake the following actions:

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (a) provide standardised templates for areas covered by this Regulation, as specified by the Board in its request;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (b) develop and maintain a single information platform providing easy to use information in relation to this Regulation for all operators across the Union;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (c) organise appropriate communication campaigns to raise awareness about the obligations arising from this Regulation;

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Article: Article 62: Measures for Providers and Deployers, in Particular SMEs, Including Start-Ups
Content: (d) evaluate and promote the convergence of best practices in public procurement procedures in relation to AI systems.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 1. Microenterprises within the meaning of Recommendation 2003/361/EC may comply with certain elements of the quality management system required by Article 17 of this Regulation in a simplified

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: Regulation in a simplified manner, provided that they do not have partner enterprises or linked enterprises within the meaning of that Recommendation. For that purpose, the Commission shall

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: purpose, the Commission shall develop guidelines on the elements of the quality management system which may be complied with in a simplified manner considering the needs of microenterprises,

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: needs of microenterprises, without affecting the level of protection or the need for compliance with the requirements in respect of high-risk AI systems.

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: 2. Paragraph 1 of this Article shall not be interpreted as exempting those operators from fulfilling any other requirements or obligations laid down in this Regulation, including those

Chapter: Chapter VI: Measures in Support of Innovation
Content: Regulation, including those established in Articles 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 72 and 73.
1. The Commission shall develop Union expertise and capabilities in the field of AI through the AI Office.
2. Member States shall facilitate the tasks entrusted to the AI Office, as reflected in this Regulation.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 1. A European Artificial Intelligence Board (the ‘Board’) is hereby established.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 2. The Board shall be composed of one representative per Member State. The European Data Protection Supervisor shall participate as observer. The AI Office shall also attend the Board’s

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: shall also attend the Board’s meetings, without taking part in the votes. Other national and Union authorities, bodies or experts may be invited to the meetings by the Board on a case by

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: by the Board on a case by case basis, where the issues discussed are of relevance for them.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 3. Each representative shall be designated by their Member State for a period of three years, renewable once.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 4. Member States shall ensure that their representatives on the Board:

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: (a) have the relevant competences and powers in their Member State so as to contribute actively to the achievement of the Board’s tasks referred to in Article 66;

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: (b) are designated as a single contact point vis-à-vis the Board and, where appropriate, taking into account Member States’ needs, as a single contact point for stakeholders;

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: (c) are empowered to facilitate consistency and coordination between national competent authorities in their Member State as regards the implementation of this Regulation, including through

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: Regulation, including through the collection of relevant data and information for the purpose of fulfilling their tasks on the Board.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 5. The designated representatives of the Member States shall adopt the Board’s rules of procedure by a two-thirds majority. The rules of procedure shall, in particular, lay down procedures

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: lay down procedures for the selection process, the duration of the mandate of, and specifications of the tasks of, the Chair, detailed arrangements for voting, and the organisation of the

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: and the organisation of the Board’s activities and those of its sub-groups.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 6. The Board shall establish two standing sub-groups to provide a platform for cooperation and exchange among market surveillance authorities and notifying authorities about issues related

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: about issues related to market surveillance and notified bodies respectively. The standing sub-group for market surveillance should act as the administrative cooperation group (ADCO) for

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: cooperation group (ADCO) for this Regulation within the meaning of Article 30 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1020. The Board may establish other standing or temporary sub-groups as appropriate

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: sub-groups as appropriate for the purpose of examining specific issues. Where appropriate, representatives of the advisory forum referred to in Article 67 may be invited to such sub-groups

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: be invited to such sub-groups or to specific meetings of those subgroups as observers.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 7. The Board shall be organised and operated so as to safeguard the objectivity and impartiality of its activities.

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: 8. The Board shall be chaired by one of the representatives of the Member States. The AI Office shall provide the secretariat for the Board, convene the meetings upon request of the Chair,

Article: Article 65: Establishment and Structure of the European Artificial Intelligence Board
Content: upon request of the Chair, and prepare the agenda in accordance with the tasks of the Board pursuant to this Regulation and its rules of procedure.
The Board shall advise and assist the Commission and the Member States in order to facilitate the consistent and effective application of this Regulation. To that end, the Board may in
To that end, the Board may in particular:
(a) contribute to the coordination among national competent authorities responsible for the application of this Regulation and, in cooperation with and subject to the agreement of the market
the agreement of the market surveillance authorities concerned, support joint activities of market surveillance authorities referred to in Article 74(11);
(b) collect and share technical and regulatory expertise and best practices among Member States;
(c) provide advice on the implementation of this Regulation, in particular as regards the enforcement of rules on general-purpose AI models;
(d) contribute to the harmonisation of administrative practices in the Member States, including in relation to the derogation from the conformity assessment procedures referred to in Article
referred to in Article 46, the functioning of AI regulatory sandboxes, and testing in real world conditions referred to in Articles 57, 59 and 60;
(e) at the request of the Commission or on its own initiative, issue recommendations and written opinions on any relevant matters related to the implementation of this Regulation and to
of this Regulation and to its consistent and effective application, including:
(i) on the development and application of codes of conduct and codes of practice pursuant to this Regulation, as well as of the Commission’s guidelines;
(ii) the evaluation and review of this Regulation pursuant to Article 112, including as regards the serious incident reports referred to in Article 73, and the functioning of the EU database
of the EU database referred to in Article 71, the preparation of the delegated or implementing acts, and as regards possible alignments of this Regulation with the Union harmonisation legislation
harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I;
(iii) on technical specifications or existing standards regarding the requirements set out in Chapter III, Section 2;
(iv) on the use of harmonised standards or common specifications referred to in Articles 40 and 41;
(v) trends, such as European global competitiveness in AI, the uptake of AI in the Union, and the development of digital skills;
(vi) trends on the evolving typology of AI value chains, in particular on the resulting implications in terms of accountability;
(vii) on the potential need for amendment to Annex III in accordance with Article 7, and on the potential need for possible revision of Article 5 pursuant to Article 112, taking into account
112, taking into account relevant available evidence and the latest developments in technology;
(f) support the Commission in promoting AI literacy, public awareness and understanding of the benefits, risks, safeguards and rights and obligations in relation to the use of AI systems;
(g) facilitate the development of common criteria and a shared understanding among market operators and competent authorities of the relevant concepts provided for in this Regulation, including
in this Regulation, including by contributing to the development of benchmarks;
(h) cooperate, as appropriate, with other Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, as well as relevant Union expert groups and networks, in particular in the fields of product
in the fields of product safety, cybersecurity, competition, digital and media services, financial services, consumer protection, data and fundamental rights protection;
(i) contribute to effective cooperation with the competent authorities of third countries and with international organisations;
(j) assist national competent authorities and the Commission in developing the organisational and technical expertise required for the implementation of this Regulation, including by contributing
including by contributing to the assessment of training needs for staff of Member States involved in implementing this Regulation;
(k) assist the AI Office in supporting national competent authorities in the establishment and development of AI regulatory sandboxes, and facilitate cooperation and information-sharing
and information-sharing among AI regulatory sandboxes;
(l) contribute to, and provide relevant advice on, the development of guidance documents;
(m) advise the Commission in relation to international matters on AI;
(n) provide opinions to the Commission on the qualified alerts regarding general-purpose AI models;
(o) receive opinions by the Member States on qualified alerts regarding general-purpose AI models, and on national experiences and practices on the monitoring and enforcement of AI systems,
enforcement of AI systems, in particular systems integrating the general-purpose AI models.
1. An advisory forum shall be established to provide technical expertise and advise the Board and the Commission, and to contribute to their tasks under this Regulation.
2. The membership of the advisory forum shall represent a balanced selection of stakeholders, including industry, start-ups, SMEs, civil society and academia. The membership of the advisory
membership of the advisory forum shall be balanced with regard to commercial and non-commercial interests and, within the category of commercial interests, with regard to SMEs and other
with regard to SMEs and other undertakings.
3. The Commission shall appoint the members of the advisory forum, in accordance with the criteria set out in paragraph 2, from amongst stakeholders with recognised expertise in the field
4. The term of office of the members of the advisory forum shall be two years, which may be extended by up to no more than four years.
5. The Fundamental Rights Agency, ENISA, the European Committee for Standardization (CEN), the European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization (CENELEC), and the European Telecommunications
European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) shall be permanent members of the advisory forum.
6. The advisory forum shall draw up its rules of procedure. It shall elect two co-chairs from among its members, in accordance with criteria set out in paragraph 2. The term of office of
2. The term of office of the co-chairs shall be two years, renewable once.
7. The advisory forum shall hold meetings at least twice a year. The advisory forum may invite experts and other stakeholders to its meetings.
8. The advisory forum may prepare opinions, recommendations and written contributions at the request of the Board or the Commission.
9. The advisory forum may establish standing or temporary sub-groups as appropriate for the purpose of examining specific questions related to the objectives of this Regulation.
10. The advisory forum shall prepare an annual report on its activities. That report shall be made publicly available.

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 1. The Commission shall, by means of an implementing act, make provisions on the establishment of a scientific panel of independent experts (the ‘scientific panel’) intended to support

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: panel’) intended to support the enforcement activities under this Regulation. That implementing act shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 2. The scientific panel shall consist of experts selected by the Commission on the basis of up-to-date scientific or technical expertise in the field of AI necessary for the tasks set out

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: for the tasks set out in paragraph 3, and shall be able to demonstrate meeting all of the following conditions:

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (a) having particular expertise and competence and scientific or technical expertise in the field of AI;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (b) independence from any provider of AI systems or general-purpose AI models;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (c) an ability to carry out activities diligently, accurately and objectively. The Commission, in consultation with the Board, shall determine the number of experts on the panel in accordance

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: on the panel in accordance with the required needs and shall ensure fair gender and geographical representation.

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 3. The scientific panel shall advise and support the AI Office, in particular with regard to the following tasks:

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (a) supporting the implementation and enforcement of this Regulation as regards general-purpose AI models and systems, in particular by:

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (i) alerting the AI Office of possible systemic risks at Union level of general-purpose AI models, in accordance with Article 90;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (ii) contributing to the development of tools and methodologies for evaluating capabilities of general-purpose AI models and systems, including through benchmarks;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (iii) providing advice on the classification of general-purpose AI models with systemic risk;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (iv) providing advice on the classification of various general-purpose AI models and systems;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (v) contributing to the development of tools and templates;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (b) supporting the work of market surveillance authorities, at their request;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (c) supporting cross-border market surveillance activities as referred to in Article 74(11), without prejudice to the powers of market surveillance authorities;

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: (d) supporting the AI Office in carrying out its duties in the context of the Union safeguard procedure pursuant to Article 81.

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 4. The experts on the scientific panel shall perform their tasks with impartiality and objectivity, and shall ensure the confidentiality of information and data obtained in carrying out

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: data obtained in carrying out their tasks and activities. They shall neither seek nor take instructions from anyone when exercising their tasks under paragraph 3. Each expert shall draw

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 3. Each expert shall draw up a declaration of interests, which shall be made publicly available. The AI Office shall establish systems and procedures to actively manage and prevent potential

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: manage and prevent potential conflicts of interest.

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: 5. The implementing act referred to in paragraph 1 shall include provisions on the conditions, procedures and detailed arrangements for the scientific panel and its members to issue alerts,

Article: Article 68: Scientific Panel of Independent Experts
Content: its members to issue alerts, and to request the assistance of the AI Office for the performance of the tasks of the scientific panel.

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: 1. Member States may call upon experts of the scientific panel to support their enforcement activities under this Regulation.

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: 2. The Member States may be required to pay fees for the advice and support provided by the experts. The structure and the level of fees as well as the scale and structure of recoverable

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: and structure of recoverable costs shall be set out in the implementing act referred to in Article 68(1), taking into account the objectives of the adequate implementation of this Regulation,

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: of this Regulation, cost-effectiveness and the necessity of ensuring effective access to experts for all Member States.

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: 3. The Commission shall facilitate timely access to the experts by the Member States, as needed, and ensure that the combination of support activities carried out by Union AI testing support

Article: Article 69: Access to the Pool of Experts by the Member States
Content: by Union AI testing support pursuant to Article 84 and experts pursuant to this Article is efficiently organised and provides the best possible added value.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 1. Each Member State shall establish or designate as national competent authorities at least one notifying authority and at least one market surveillance authority for the purposes of this

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: for the purposes of this Regulation. Those national competent authorities shall exercise their powers independently, impartially and without bias so as to safeguard the objectivity of their

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: the objectivity of their activities and tasks, and to ensure the application and implementation of this Regulation. The members of those authorities shall refrain from any action incompatible

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: from any action incompatible with their duties. Provided that those principles are observed, such activities and tasks may be performed by one or more designated authorities, in accordance

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: authorities, in accordance with the organisational needs of the Member State.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 2. Member States shall communicate to the Commission the identity of the notifying authorities and the market surveillance authorities and the tasks of those authorities, as well as any

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: authorities, as well as any subsequent changes thereto. Member States shall make publicly available information on how competent authorities and single points of contact can be contacted,

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: of contact can be contacted, through electronic communication means by 2 August 2025. Member States shall designate a market surveillance authority to act as the single point of contact

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: the single point of contact for this Regulation, and shall notify the Commission of the identity of the single point of contact. The Commission shall make a list of the single points of

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: list of the single points of contact publicly available.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 3. Member States shall ensure that their national competent authorities are provided with adequate technical, financial and human resources, and with infrastructure to fulfil their tasks

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: to fulfil their tasks effectively under this Regulation. In particular, the national competent authorities shall have a sufficient number of personnel permanently available whose competences

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: available whose competences and expertise shall include an in-depth understanding of AI technologies, data and data computing, personal data protection, cybersecurity, fundamental rights,

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: fundamental rights, health and safety risks and knowledge of existing standards and legal requirements. Member States shall assess and, if necessary, update competence and resource requirements

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: and resource requirements referred to in this paragraph on an annual basis.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 4. National competent authorities shall take appropriate measures to ensure an adequate level of cybersecurity.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 5. When performing their tasks, the national competent authorities shall act in accordance with the confidentiality obligations set out in Article 78.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 6. By 2 August 2025, and once every two years thereafter, Member States shall report to the Commission on the status of the financial and human resources of the national competent authorities,

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: competent authorities, with an assessment of their adequacy. The Commission shall transmit that information to the Board for discussion and possible recommendations.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 7. The Commission shall facilitate the exchange of experience between national competent authorities.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 8. National competent authorities may provide guidance and advice on the implementation of this Regulation, in particular to SMEs including start-ups, taking into account the guidance and

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: into account the guidance and advice of the Board and the Commission, as appropriate. Whenever national competent authorities intend to provide guidance and advice with regard to an AI

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: advice with regard to an AI system in areas covered by other Union law, the national competent authorities under that Union law shall be consulted, as appropriate.

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: 9. Where Union institutions, bodies, offices or agencies fall within the scope of this Regulation, the European Data Protection Supervisor shall act as the competent authority for their

Article: Article 70: Designation of National Competent Authorities and Single Point of Contact
Content: competent authority for their supervision.

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 1. The Commission shall, in collaboration with the Member States, set up and maintain an EU database containing information referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article concerning

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 3 of this Article concerning high-risk AI systems referred to in Article 6(2) which are registered in accordance with Articles 49 and 60 and AI systems that are not considered as high-risk

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: not considered as high-risk pursuant to Article 6(3) and which are registered in accordance with Article 6(4) and Article 49. When setting the functional specifications of such database,

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: of such database, the Commission shall consult the relevant experts, and when updating the functional specifications of such database, the Commission shall consult the Board.

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 2. The data listed in Sections A and B of Annex VIII shall be entered into the EU database by the provider or, where applicable, by the authorised representative.

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 3. The data listed in Section C of Annex VIII shall be entered into the EU database by the deployer who is, or who acts on behalf of, a public authority, agency or body, in accordance with

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: or body, in accordance with Article 49(3) and (4).

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 4. With the exception of the section referred to in Article 49(4) and Article 60(4), point (c), the information contained in the EU database registered in accordance with Article 49 shall

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: with Article 49 shall be accessible and publicly available in a user-friendly manner. The information should be easily navigable and machine-readable. The information registered in accordance

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: registered in accordance with Article 60 shall be accessible only to market surveillance authorities and the Commission, unless the prospective provider or provider has given consent for

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: has given consent for also making the information accessible the public.

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 5. The EU database shall contain personal data only in so far as necessary for collecting and processing information in accordance with this Regulation. That information shall include the

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: information shall include the names and contact details of natural persons who are responsible for registering the system and have the legal authority to represent the provider or the deployer,

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: the provider or the deployer, as applicable.

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: 6. The Commission shall be the controller of the EU database. It shall make available to providers, prospective providers and deployers adequate technical and administrative support. The

Chapter: Chapter VIII: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems
Article: Article 71: EU Database for High-Risk AI Systems Listed in Annex III
Content: administrative support. The EU database shall comply with the applicable accessibility requirements.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Article: Article 72: Post-Market Monitoring by Providers and Post-Market Monitoring Plan for High-Risk AI Systems
Content: 1. Providers shall establish and document a post-market monitoring system in a manner that is proportionate to the nature of the AI technologies and the risks of the high-risk AI system.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Article: Article 72: Post-Market Monitoring by Providers and Post-Market Monitoring Plan for High-Risk AI Systems
Content: 2. The post-market monitoring system shall actively and systematically collect, document and analyse relevant data which may be provided by deployers or which may be collected through other

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Article: Article 72: Post-Market Monitoring by Providers and Post-Market Monitoring Plan for High-Risk AI Systems
Content: be collected through other sources on the performance of high-risk AI systems throughout their lifetime, and which allow the provider to evaluate the continuous compliance of AI systems

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Article: Article 72: Post-Market Monitoring by Providers and Post-Market Monitoring Plan for High-Risk AI Systems

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 1. For the purpose of carrying out the tasks assigned to it under this Section, the AI Office may take the necessary actions to monitor the effective implementation and compliance with

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 2. Downstream providers shall have the right to lodge a complaint alleging an infringement of this Regulation. A complaint shall be duly reasoned and indicate at least:

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: (c) any other information that the downstream provider that sent the request considers relevant, including, where appropriate, information gathered on its own initiative.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 1. The AI Office, after consulting the Board, may conduct evaluations of the general-purpose AI model concerned:

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance

Content: on behalf of the provider of the general-purpose AI model concerned.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 7. Prior to requesting access to the general-purpose AI model concerned, the AI Office may initiate a structured dialogue with the provider of the general-purpose AI model to gather more

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: AI model to gather more information on the internal testing of the model, internal safeguards for preventing systemic risks, and other internal procedures and measures the provider has

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 1. Where necessary and appropriate, the Commission may request providers to:

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: (a) take appropriate measures to comply with the obligations set out in Articles 53 and 54;

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: (b) implement mitigation measures, where the evaluation carried out in accordance with Article 92 has given rise to serious and substantiated concern of a systemic risk at Union level;

Content: (c) restrict the making available on the market, withdraw or recall the model.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 2. Before a measure is requested, the AI Office may initiate a structured dialogue with the provider of the general-purpose AI model.

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: 3. If, during the structured dialogue referred to in paragraph 2, the provider of the general-purpose AI model with systemic risk offers commitments to implement mitigation measures to

Chapter: Chapter IX: Post-Market Monitoring, Information Sharing and Market Surveillance
Content: mitigation measures to address a systemic risk at Union level, the Commission may, by decision, make those commitments binding and declare that there are no further grounds for action.

Content: persons with a disability, as well as on gender equality.

Chapter: Chapter X: Codes of Conduct and Guidelines

Content: 3. Codes of conduct may be drawn up by individual providers or deployers of AI systems or by organisations representing them or by both, including with the involvement of any interested

Chapter: Chapter X: Codes of Conduct and Guidelines

Chapter: Chapter XI: Delegation of Power and Committee Procedure
Content: 1. The Commission shall be assisted by a committee. That committee shall be a committee within the meaning of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.

Chapter: Chapter XI: Delegation of Power and Committee Procedure
Content: 2. Where reference is made to this paragraph, Article 5 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 shall apply.
1. In accordance with the terms and conditions laid down in this Regulation, Member States shall lay down the rules on penalties and other enforcement measures, which may also include warnings
may also include warnings and non-monetary measures, applicable to infringements of this Regulation by operators, and shall take all measures necessary to ensure that they are properly
ensure that they are properly and effectively implemented, thereby taking into account the guidelines issued by the Commission pursuant to Article 96. The penalties provided for shall be
provided for shall be effective, proportionate and dissuasive. They shall take into account the interests of SMEs, including start-ups, and their economic viability.
2. The Member States shall, without delay and at the latest by the date of entry into application, notify the Commission of the rules on penalties and of other enforcement measures referred
enforcement measures referred to in paragraph 1, and shall notify it, without delay, of any subsequent amendment to them.
3. Non-compliance with the prohibition of the AI practices referred to in Article 5 shall be subject to administrative fines of up to 35 000 000 EUR or, if the offender is an undertaking,
offender is an undertaking, up to 7 % of its total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.
4. Non-compliance with any of the following provisions related to operators or notified bodies, other than those laid down in Articles 5, shall be subject to administrative fines of up
to administrative fines of up to 15 000 000 EUR or, if the offender is an undertaking, up to 3 % of its total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher:
(a) obligations of providers pursuant to Article 16;
(b) obligations of authorised representatives pursuant to Article 22;
(c) obligations of importers pursuant to Article 23;
(d) obligations of distributors pursuant to Article 24;
(e) obligations of deployers pursuant to Article 26;
(f) requirements and obligations of notified bodies pursuant to Article 31, Article 33(1), (3) and (4) or Article 34;
(g) transparency obligations for providers and deployers pursuant to Article 50.
5. The supply of incorrect, incomplete or misleading information to notified bodies or national competent authorities in reply to a request shall be subject to administrative fines of up
to administrative fines of up to 7 500 000 EUR or, if the offender is an undertaking, up to 1 % of its total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.
6. In the case of SMEs, including start-ups, each fine referred to in this Article shall be up to the percentages or amount referred to in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5, whichever thereof is lower.
7. When deciding whether to impose an administrative fine and when deciding on the amount of the administrative fine in each individual case, all relevant circumstances of the specific
circumstances of the specific situation shall be taken into account and, as appropriate, regard shall be given to the following:
(a) the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement and of its consequences, taking into account the purpose of the AI system, as well as, where appropriate, the number of affected
the number of affected persons and the level of damage suffered by them;
(b) whether administrative fines have already been applied by other market surveillance authorities to the same operator for the same infringement;
(c) whether administrative fines have already been applied by other authorities to the same operator for infringements of other Union or national law, when such infringements result from
infringements result from the same activity or omission constituting a relevant infringement of this Regulation;
(d) the size, the annual turnover and market share of the operator committing the infringement;
(e) any other aggravating or mitigating factor applicable to the circumstances of the case, such as financial benefits gained, or losses avoided, directly or indirectly, from the infringement;
(f) the degree of cooperation with the national competent authorities, in order to remedy the infringement and mitigate the possible adverse effects of the infringement;
(g) the degree of responsibility of the operator taking into account the technical and organisational measures implemented by it;
(h) the manner in which the infringement became known to the national competent authorities, in particular whether, and if so to what extent, the operator notified the infringement;
(i) the intentional or negligent character of the infringement;
(j) any action taken by the operator to mitigate the harm suffered by the affected persons.
8. Each Member State shall lay down rules on to what extent administrative fines may be imposed on public authorities and bodies established in that Member State.
9. Depending on the legal system of the Member States, the rules on administrative fines may be applied in such a manner that the fines are imposed by competent national courts or by other
national courts or by other bodies, as applicable in those Member States. The application of such rules in those Member States shall have an equivalent effect.
10. The exercise of powers under this Article shall be subject to appropriate procedural safeguards in accordance with Union and national law, including effective judicial remedies and
judicial remedies and due process.
11. Member States shall, on an annual basis, report to the Commission about the administrative fines they have issued during that year, in accordance with this Article, and about any related
and about any related litigation or judicial proceedings.
